prompt: Which buses does each AC power system consists of?
answer: Transfer bus (1);  Main bus (1); Galley buses (2); Ground Service Bus (1).
affects_bus: main buses; galley buses; ground service bus(es)

prompt: If the AC source powering an AC transfer bus fails or is disconnected, how can that transfer bus be powered?
answer: It can be powered by any available source through the tie bus via the bus tie breakers (BTBs).
failure_logic: It can be powered by any available source through the tie bus via the bus tie breakers (BTBs).

prompt: What does selecting GRD PWR Switch ON do on the ground with both generators off the bus?
answer: If ground power available: removes previously connected power from AC transfer buses; connects ground power to AC transfer buses if power quality is correct

prompt: What does selecting either APU GEN switch to ON do to the AC transfer buses?
answer: If neither AC transfer bus powered by IDG: - Connects both AC transfer buses to APU generator; disconnected external power, illuminates opposite SOURCE OFF light until other APU GEN switch moved to ON. If both AC transfer buses powered by IDGs: - Powers the related transfer bus from the APU generator; - Other transfer bus continues to receive power from the IDG

prompt: Can one AC transfer bus be powered by external power while the other is powered by the APU?
answer: No.

prompt: GEN switch (ENG) — what does OFF do?
answer: Disconnects the IDG from the related AC transfer bus by opening the generator circuit breaker.

prompt: GEN switch (ENG) — what does ON do (momentary)?
answer: Connects the IDG to the related AC transfer bus by disconnecting the previous power source and closing the generator circuit breaker.

prompt: In flight, with one engine generator no longer supplying power and BUS TRANSFER in AUTO, what happens to the transfer buses?
answer: BTBs automatically close so the remaining generator can supply both transfer buses through the tie bus/BTBs.
failure_logic: BTBs automatically close so the remaining generator can supply both transfer buses through the tie bus/BTBs.
affects_bus: AC transfer buses; tie bus; BTBs

prompt: If the airplane takes off with the APU powering both transfer buses and the APU is shut down or fails, what happens? How many times can this occur?
answer: - Engine generators are automatically connected to their related AC transfer buses. - This occurs only once in flight and only in that circumstance.
failure_logic: - Engine generators are automatically connected to their related AC transfer buses. - This occurs only once in flight and only in that circumstance.

prompt: BUS TRANSFER switch — AUTO (guarded): what does it allow for AC and DC?
answer: AC: BTBs operate automatically to maintain power to AC transfer buses from any operating generator or external power. DC: DC cross tie relay automatically provides normal or isolated operation as required.

prompt: BUS TRANSFER switch — OFF: what does it do (AC + DC + TR3 input)?
answer: AC: isolates AC transfer bus 1 from AC transfer bus 2 (if one IDG is supplying both). DC: DC cross tie relay opens to isolate DC bus 1 from DC bus 2. Also inhibits TR3 input from connecting to AC transfer bus 1.
affects_bus: AC transfer bus 1; AC transfer bus 2; TR3; DC bus 1; DC bus 2; DC buses

prompt: What is the order of load shedding during single generator operation?
answer: Sheds incrementally: (1) galleys and main bus on transfer bus 2; (2) galleys and main bus on transfer bus 1; (3) IFE buses.
failure_logic: Sheds incrementally: (1) galleys and main bus on transfer bus 2; (2) galleys and main bus on transfer bus 1; (3) IFE buses.
affects_bus: AC transfer bus 1; AC transfer bus 2; main buses; IFE buses

prompt: When source capacity returns to two-generator operation, what restores automatically and what requires CAB/UTIL reset?
answer: IFE/PASS buses restore automatically. Galley and main bus power require CAB/UTIL switch reset (OFF then ON) to restore.
failure_logic: IFE/PASS buses restore automatically. Galley and main bus power require CAB/UTIL switch reset (OFF then ON) to restore.

prompt: Which AC transfer bus powers TR1 and TR2?
answer: TR1 receives AC power from transfer bus 1. TR2 receives AC power from transfer bus 2.
affects_bus: AC transfer bus 1; AC transfer bus 2; TR1; TR2

prompt: TR3 normally receives AC power from which transfer bus, and what is its backup source (when BUS TRANSFER is AUTO)?
answer: Normally from transfer bus 2, with backup AC power from transfer bus 1.
normal_state: Normally from transfer bus 2, with backup AC power from transfer bus 1.
affects_bus: AC transfer bus 1; AC transfer bus 2; TR3

prompt: What AC indications are provided on the AC/DC metering pane?
answer: Voltage, Current, and Frequency of the selected AC source.

prompt: What DC indications are provided on the AC/DC metering pane?
answer: Voltage and Current of the selected DC source.

prompt: What does the OFF position of the GRD PWR switch do?
answer: Disconnects ground power from the AC transfer buses.

prompt: What happens when the GRD PWR switch is  moved to ON (with ground power available)?
answer: Removes previously connected power from AC transfer buses, then connects ground power to the AC transfer buses (if power quality is correct).

prompt: What does the TRANSFER BUS OFF light indicate?
answer: The related AC transfer bus is not powered.
normal_state: The related AC transfer bus is not powered.

prompt: What does the GEN OFF BUS light indicate"?
answer: IDG is not supplying power to the related AC transfer bus.
normal_state: IDG is not supplying power to the related AC transfer bus.

prompt: DC power system: what supplies 28V DC power under normal conditions?
answer: Three transformer-rectifier (TR) units energized from the AC transfer buses supply 28V DC.
normal_state: Three transformer-rectifier (TR) units energized from the AC transfer buses supply 28V DC.

prompt: What are the two basic principles of operation for the B737 electrical system?
answer: No paralleling of AC sources. Connecting a source to a transfer bus automatically disconnects an existing source.
interacts_with: AC sources; transfer buses; bus tie logic
notes: Consider splitting into 2 bullets in answer (principle 1: no paralleling; principle 2: auto-disconnect on transfer bus).

prompt: What are the three main divisions of the B737 electrical power system?
answer: AC power system; DC power system; standby power system.
interacts_with: AC power; DC power; standby power

prompt: APU-only electrical power in flight: what is shed automatically (and what else if overload persists)?
answer: All galley buses and main buses are automatically shed. If load still exceeds limits, both IFE buses are also automatically shed.
failure_logic: Automatic load shedding in-flight on APU-only power: sheds galley+main; if overload persists, sheds both IFE buses.
affects_bus: galley buses; main buses; IFE buses

prompt: APU on the ground with overload sensed: what does the APU shed, and how can you attempt restoration?
answer: Sheds galley buses and main buses until load is within limits. Restoration can be attempted by moving CAB/UTIL switch OFF then back ON.
failure_logic: Ground APU overload: sheds galley+main until within limits; restoration attempt via CAB/UTIL OFF → ON.

prompt: TR units convert what to what?
answer: Convert 115V AC to 28V DC.
notes: If you later create device cards, consider tags like device:TR.

prompt: How many TRs are required to supply the total connected load?
answer: Any two TRs are capable of supplying the total connected load.
notes: Reliability concept: 2 TRs can carry total connected DC load (3rd provides redundancy margin).

prompt: Under normal conditions, what does TR3 power and what is its role?
answer: TR3 powers the battery bus and serves as a backup power source for TR1 and TR2.
normal_state: TR3 powers the battery bus and serves as a backup power source for TR1 and TR2.
notes: TR3 normally powers battery bus; can back up TR1/TR2 if they fail.

prompt: Under which two conditions does the cross bus tie relay open?
answer: At glideslope capture during a flight director or autopilot ILS approach; and when the BUS TRANSFER switch is positioned to OFF.
failure_logic: At glideslope capture during a flight director or autopilot ILS approach; and when the BUS TRANSFER switch is positioned to OFF.
interacts_with: cross bus tie relay; BUS TRANSFER switch; ILS logic (GS capture)
ref_section: Ch 6 §6.20.5 (Cross bus tie relay) + §6.10.4 (BUS TRANSFER OFF)
notes: Consider splitting into 2 bullets: (1) GS capture condition; (2) BUS TRANSFER OFF condition.

prompt: TR UNIT light: when does it illuminate in flight vs on the ground?
answer: In flight: illuminates if: [TR1 OR  (TR2 AND TR3)]  has failed. On the ground: any TR fault causes the light to illuminate.
normal_state: In flight: illuminates if: [TR1 OR  (TR2 AND TR3)]  has failed. On the ground: any TR fault causes the light to illuminate.

prompt: ELEC light: what does it indicate on the ground and in-flight?
answer: On the ground: indicates a fault exists in the DC power system or standby power system. In flight: ELEC light is inhibited.
normal_state: On the ground: indicates a fault exists in the DC power system or standby power system. In flight: ELEC light is inhibited.
interacts_with: DC power system; standby power system

prompt: What does the Static Inverter do?
answer: Converts 24V DC from the battery to 115V AC to supply the AC standby bus during loss of normal electrical power.

prompt: What controls the Static Inverter's power supply?
answer: The standby power switch and the battery switch on the overhead panel.

prompt: What does the GROUND SERVICE do?
answer: Connects/disconnects external power to the ground service buses without activating AC transfer buses.

prompt: What does the GRD POWER AVAILABLE light mean?
answer: Ground power is connected and meets airplane power quality standards.
normal_state: Ground power is connected and meets airplane power quality standards.

prompt: What does the SOURCE OFF light indicate?
answer: No source has been manually selected to power the related AC transfer bus, or the manually selected source has been disconnected.
normal_state: No source has been manually selected to power the related AC transfer bus, or the manually selected source has been disconnected.

prompt: Which AC transfer bus powers the AC standby bus under normal conditions?
answer: Transfer bus 1 supplies the AC standby bus.
normal_state: Transfer bus 1 supplies the AC standby bus.
affects_bus: AC transfer bus 1; AC standby bus

prompt: Under normal conditions, how are DC bus 1, DC bus 2, and the DC standby buses powered? How are they connected to one another?
answer: .TR1 and TR2 each power DC bus 1, DC bus 2, and the DC standby bus. They are connected via the cross bus tie relay;
normal_state: .TR1 and TR2 each power DC bus 1, DC bus 2, and the DC standby bus. They are connected via the cross bus tie relay;
affects_bus: TR1; TR2; DC bus 1; DC bus 2; DC buses
ref_section: Ch 6 §6.20.5 (DC buses / cross bus tie relay)

prompt: What is the chemistry and nominal voltage of the battery? Where is it located?
answer: 24V nickel-cadmium battery;  located in the electronics compartment.

prompt: How long is the fully-charged battery capable of providing standby power?
answer: Minimum of 30 minutes.

prompt: What is the battery voltage range?
answer: 22–30 volts.

prompt: After loss of both generators, which DC buses does the battery power?
answer: Battery bus; DC standby bus;Hot battery bus; Switched hot battery bus.
failure_logic: Battery bus; DC standby bus;Hot battery bus; Switched hot battery bus.

prompt: When is the Switched Hot Battery Bus powered?
answer: Whenever the battery switch is ON.

prompt: How is the Hot Battery Bus connected to the battery?
answer: Directly.

prompt: What does the Standby Power System provide and when?
answer: Provides 115V AC and 24V DC power to essential systems in the event of loss of all engine or APU-driven AC power.

prompt: What are the components (2) and buses (5) that comprise the Standby Power System
answer: Static inverter;  main battery.; AC standby bus; DC standby bus; battery bus; hot battery bus; switched hot battery bus.

prompt: With both AC Transfer Buses powered by their generators and the guards down on the BAT and STANDBY POWER switches, what powers the following buses: AC Standby Bus; DC Standby Bus; Battery Bus; Hot Battery Bus; Switched Hot Battery Bus?
answer: In the Normal Standby Power System Configuration, what powers the following buses?  AC Standby Bus: AC Transfer Bus #1; DC Standby Bus: TR1, TR2, and TR3; Battery Bus: TR3; Hot Battery Bus: Battery and/or Battery Charger; Switched Hot Battery Bus: Battery and/or Battery Charger.
affects_bus: AC transfer buses; battery bus; AC standby bus; TR1; TR2; TR3

prompt: With the loss of all AC generators and the guards down on the BATTERY  and STANDBY POWER switches, what powers the following buses: AC Standby Bus; DC Standby Bus; Battery Bus; Hot Battery Bus; Switched Hot Battery Bus?
answer: With the loss of all AC generators and the guards down on the BATTERY  and STANDBY POWER switches, what powers the following buses: AC Standby Bus: Battery via static inverter; DC Standby Bus: battery; Battery Bus: battery; Hot Battery Bus: battery; Switched Hot Battery Bus: battery?
failure_logic: With the loss of all AC generators and the guards down on the BATTERY  and STANDBY POWER switches, what powers the following buses: AC Standby Bus: Battery via static inverter; DC Standby Bus: battery; Battery Bus: battery; Hot Battery Bus: battery; Switched Hot Battery Bus: battery?

prompt: Standby power switch — AUTO: when does automatic switching from normal to alternate occur?
answer: If power from either AC transfer bus 1 or DC bus 1 is lost.
affects_bus: AC transfer bus 1; DC bus 1; DC buses

prompt: Standby power switch — BAT: what does it do (and what happens if BAT switch is OFF)?
answer: Overrides automatic switching and places AC standby bus, DC standby bus, and battery bus on battery power. Battery switch may be ON or OFF; if battery switch is OFF, the switched hot battery bus is not powered.

prompt: Standby power switch — OFF: what happens?
answer: De-energizes AC standby bus and DC standby bus and illuminates the STANDBY PWR OFF light.
